trans-unit.source: Setting up services required to publish a cloud service from Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Setting up services required to publish a cloud service from Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Learn the procedures to set up cloud and storage account services and configure your Azure application
trans-unit.target: Learn the procedures to set up cloud and storage account services and configure your Azure application

trans-unit.source: Before you can publish a cloud service project, you must set up the following services:
trans-unit.target: Before you can publish a cloud service project, you must set up the following services:

trans-unit.source: A cloud service to run your roles in the Azure environment
trans-unit.target: A cloud service to run your roles in the Azure environment

trans-unit.source: A storage account that provides access to the Blob, Queue, and Table services.
trans-unit.target: A storage account that provides access to the Blob, Queue, and Table services.

trans-unit.source: Use the following procedures to set up these services and configure your application
trans-unit.target: Use the following procedures to set up these services and configure your application

trans-unit.source: To publish a cloud service to Azure, you must first create a cloud service, which runs your roles in the Azure environment.
trans-unit.target: To publish a cloud service to Azure, you must first create a cloud service, which runs your roles in the Azure environment.

trans-unit.source: You can create a cloud service in the Azure Management Portal, as described <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can create a cloud service in the Azure Management Portal, as described <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can also create a cloud service in Visual Studio when you use the publishing wizard.
trans-unit.target: You can also create a cloud service in Visual Studio when you use the publishing wizard.

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for the Azure project, and choose Publish.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for the Azure project, and choose Publish.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VST_PublishMenu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VST_PublishMenu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you haven't signed in, sign in with your username and password for the Microsoft account or organizational account that's associated with your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't signed in, sign in with your username and password for the Microsoft account or organizational account that's associated with your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Next button to advance to the Settings page.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Next button to advance to the Settings page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publishing Wizard Common Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publishing Wizard Common Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Cloud Services list, choose Create New.
trans-unit.target: In the Cloud Services list, choose Create New.

trans-unit.source: The Create Azure Services dialog appears.
trans-unit.target: The Create Azure Services dialog appears.

trans-unit.source: Enter the name of your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Enter the name of your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: The name forms part of the URL for your service and therefore must be globally unique.
trans-unit.target: The name forms part of the URL for your service and therefore must be globally unique.

trans-unit.source: The name is not case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: The name is not case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: (optional) To display a list of cloud services that you've already created, choose the Cloud Services link on the left side of the page.
trans-unit.target: (optional) To display a list of cloud services that you've already created, choose the Cloud Services link on the left side of the page.

trans-unit.source: Choose the + icon in the lower-left corner, and then choose Cloud Service on the menu that appears.
trans-unit.target: Choose the + icon in the lower-left corner, and then choose Cloud Service on the menu that appears.

trans-unit.source: Another screen with two options, Quick Create and Custom Create, appears.
trans-unit.target: Another screen with two options, Quick Create and Custom Create, appears.

trans-unit.source: If you choose Quick Create, you can create a cloud service just by specifying its URL and the region where it will be physically hosted.
trans-unit.target: If you choose Quick Create, you can create a cloud service just by specifying its URL and the region where it will be physically hosted.

trans-unit.source: If you choose Custom Create, you can immediately publish a cloud service by specifying a package (.cspkg file), a configuration (.cscfg) file, and a certificate.
trans-unit.target: If you choose Custom Create, you can immediately publish a cloud service by specifying a package (.cspkg file), a configuration (.cscfg) file, and a certificate.

trans-unit.source: Custom Create isn’t required if you intend to publish your cloud service by using the Publish command in an Azure project.
trans-unit.target: Custom Create isn’t required if you intend to publish your cloud service by using the Publish command in an Azure project.

trans-unit.source: The Publish command is available on the shortcut menu for an Azure project.
trans-unit.target: The Publish command is available on the shortcut menu for an Azure project.

trans-unit.source: Choose Quick Create to later publish your cloud service by using Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Choose Quick Create to later publish your cloud service by using Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Specify a name for your cloud service.The complete URL appears next to the name.
trans-unit.target: Specify a name for your cloud service.The complete URL appears next to the name.

trans-unit.source: In the list, choose the region where most of your users are located.
trans-unit.target: In the list, choose the region where most of your users are located.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the window, choose the Create Cloud Service link.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the window, choose the Create Cloud Service link.

trans-unit.source: A storage account provides access to the Blob, Queue, and Table services.
trans-unit.target: A storage account provides access to the Blob, Queue, and Table services.

trans-unit.source: You can create a storage account by using Visual Studio or the <linkText>Azure Platform Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can create a storage account by using Visual Studio or the <linkText>Azure Platform Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Storage node, and then choose Create Storage Account.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Storage node, and then choose Create Storage Account.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a new Azure storage account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a new Azure storage account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select or enter the following information for the new storage account in the Create Storage Account dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Select or enter the following information for the new storage account in the Create Storage Account dialog box.

trans-unit.source: The Azure subscription to which you want to add the storage account.
trans-unit.target: The Azure subscription to which you want to add the storage account.

trans-unit.source: The name you want to use for the new storage account.
trans-unit.target: The name you want to use for the new storage account.

trans-unit.source: The region or affinity group (such as West US or East Asia).
trans-unit.target: The region or affinity group (such as West US or East Asia).

trans-unit.source: The type of replication you want to use for the storage account, such as Geo-Redundant.
trans-unit.target: The type of replication you want to use for the storage account, such as Geo-Redundant.

trans-unit.source: When you’re done, choose Create.The new storage account appears in the Storage list in Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: When you’re done, choose Create.The new storage account appears in the Storage list in Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the <linkText>Azure Platform Management Portal</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the <linkText>Azure Platform Management Portal</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: (optional) To view your storage accounts, choose the Storage link in the panel on the left side of the page.
trans-unit.target: (optional) To view your storage accounts, choose the Storage link in the panel on the left side of the page.

trans-unit.source: In the lower-left corner of the page, choose the + icon.
trans-unit.target: In the lower-left corner of the page, choose the + icon.

trans-unit.source: In the menu that appears, choose Storage, and then choose Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: In the menu that appears, choose Storage, and then choose Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: Give the storage account a name that will result in a unique url.
trans-unit.target: Give the storage account a name that will result in a unique url.

trans-unit.source: Give your cloud service a name.
trans-unit.target: Give your cloud service a name.

trans-unit.source: The complete URL appears next to the name.
trans-unit.target: The complete URL appears next to the name.

trans-unit.source: In the list of regions, choose a region where most of your users are located.
trans-unit.target: In the list of regions, choose a region where most of your users are located.

trans-unit.source: Specify whether you want to enable geo-replication.
trans-unit.target: Specify whether you want to enable geo-replication.

trans-unit.source: If you enable geo-replication, your data will be saved in multiple physical locations to reduce the chance of loss.
trans-unit.target: If you enable geo-replication, your data will be saved in multiple physical locations to reduce the chance of loss.

trans-unit.source: This feature makes storage more expensive, but you can reduce the cost by enabling geo-location when you create the storage account instead of adding the feature later.
trans-unit.target: This feature makes storage more expensive, but you can reduce the cost by enabling geo-location when you create the storage account instead of adding the feature later.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Geo-replication</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Geo-replication</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the window, choose the Create Storage Account link.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the window, choose the Create Storage Account link.

trans-unit.source: After you create your storage account, you will see the URLs that you can use to access resources in each of the Azure storage services, and also the primary and secondary access keys for your account.
trans-unit.target: After you create your storage account, you will see the URLs that you can use to access resources in each of the Azure storage services, and also the primary and secondary access keys for your account.

trans-unit.source: You use these keys to authenticate requests made against the storage services.
trans-unit.target: You use these keys to authenticate requests made against the storage services.

trans-unit.source: The secondary access key provides the same access to your storage account as the primary access key and is generated as a backup should your primary access key be compromised.
trans-unit.target: The secondary access key provides the same access to your storage account as the primary access key and is generated as a backup should your primary access key be compromised.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, it is recommended that you regenerate your access keys on a regular basis.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, it is recommended that you regenerate your access keys on a regular basis.

trans-unit.source: You can modify a connection string setting to use the secondary key while you regenerate the primary key, then you can modify it to use the regenerated primary key while you regenerate the secondary key.
trans-unit.target: You can modify a connection string setting to use the secondary key while you regenerate the primary key, then you can modify it to use the regenerated primary key while you regenerate the secondary key.

trans-unit.source: You must configure any role that accesses storage services to use the Azure storage services that you have created.
trans-unit.target: You must configure any role that accesses storage services to use the Azure storage services that you have created.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you can use multiple service configurations for your Azure project.
trans-unit.target: To do this, you can use multiple service configurations for your Azure project.

trans-unit.source: By default, two are created in your Azure project.
trans-unit.target: By default, two are created in your Azure project.

trans-unit.source: By using multiple service configurations, you can use the same connection string in your code, but have a different value for a connection string in each service configuration.
trans-unit.target: By using multiple service configurations, you can use the same connection string in your code, but have a different value for a connection string in each service configuration.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can use one service configuration to run and debug your application locally using the Azure storage emulator and a different service configuration to publish your application to Azure.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can use one service configuration to run and debug your application locally using the Azure storage emulator and a different service configuration to publish your application to Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information about service configurations, see <linkText>Configuring an Azure Project</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about service configurations, see <linkText>Configuring an Azure Project</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio open your Azure solution.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio open your Azure solution.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for each role in your Azure project that accesses the storage services and choose Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for each role in your Azure project that accesses the storage services and choose Properties.

trans-unit.source: A page with the name of the role is displayed in the Visual Studio editor.
trans-unit.target: A page with the name of the role is displayed in the Visual Studio editor.

trans-unit.source: The page displays the fields for the Configuration tab.
trans-unit.target: The page displays the fields for the Configuration tab.

trans-unit.source: In the property pages for the role, choose Settings.
trans-unit.target: In the property pages for the role, choose Settings.

trans-unit.source: In the Service Configuration list, choose the name of the service configuration that you want to edit.
trans-unit.target: In the Service Configuration list, choose the name of the service configuration that you want to edit.

trans-unit.source: If you want to make changes to all of the service configurations for this role, you can choose All Configurations.
trans-unit.target: If you want to make changes to all of the service configurations for this role, you can choose All Configurations.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to update service configurations, see <linkText>Manage Connection Strings for Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to update service configurations, see <linkText>Manage Connection Strings for Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To modify any connection string settings, choose the … button next to the setting.
trans-unit.target: To modify any connection string settings, choose the … button next to the setting.

trans-unit.source: The Create Storage Connection String dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The Create Storage Connection String dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: Under Connect using, choose the Your subscription option.
trans-unit.target: Under Connect using, choose the Your subscription option.

trans-unit.source: In the Subscription list, choose your subscription.
trans-unit.target: In the Subscription list, choose your subscription.

trans-unit.source: If the list of subscriptions doesn't include the one that you want, choose the Download Publish Settings link.
trans-unit.target: If the list of subscriptions doesn't include the one that you want, choose the Download Publish Settings link.

trans-unit.source: In the Account name list, choose your storage account name.
trans-unit.target: In the Account name list, choose your storage account name.

trans-unit.source: Azure Tools obtains storage account credentials automatically by using the .publishsettings file.
trans-unit.target: Azure Tools obtains storage account credentials automatically by using the .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.source: To specify your storage account credentials manually, choose the Manually entered credentials option, and then continue with this procedure.
trans-unit.target: To specify your storage account credentials manually, choose the Manually entered credentials option, and then continue with this procedure.

trans-unit.source: You can get your storage account name and primary key from the <linkText>Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can get your storage account name and primary key from the <linkText>Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t want to specify your storage account settings manually, choose the OK button to close the dialog box.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t want to specify your storage account settings manually, choose the OK button to close the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Enter storage account credentials link.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Enter storage account credentials link.

trans-unit.source: In the Account name box, enter the name of your storage account.
trans-unit.target: In the Account name box, enter the name of your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Log into the Management Portal, and then choose the Storage button.
trans-unit.target: Log into the Management Portal, and then choose the Storage button.

trans-unit.source: The portal shows a list of storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: The portal shows a list of storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: If you choose an account, a page for it opens.
trans-unit.target: If you choose an account, a page for it opens.

trans-unit.source: You can copy the name of the storage account from this page.
trans-unit.target: You can copy the name of the storage account from this page.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a previous version of the Management Portal, the name of your storage account appears in the Storage Accounts view of the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a previous version of the Management Portal, the name of your storage account appears in the Storage Accounts view of the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: To copy this name, highlight it in the Properties window of this view, and then choose the Ctrl-C keys.
trans-unit.target: To copy this name, highlight it in the Properties window of this view, and then choose the Ctrl-C keys.

trans-unit.source: To paste the name into Visual Studio, choose the Account name text box, and then choose the Ctrl+V keys.
trans-unit.target: To paste the name into Visual Studio, choose the Account name text box, and then choose the Ctrl+V keys.

trans-unit.source: In the Account key box, enter your primary key, or copy and paste it from the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: In the Account key box, enter your primary key, or copy and paste it from the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: To copy this key from the Management Portal:
trans-unit.target: To copy this key from the Management Portal:

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the page for the appropriate storage account, choose the Manage Keys button.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the page for the appropriate storage account, choose the Manage Keys button.

trans-unit.source: On the Manage Keys Access page, select the text of the primary access key, and then choose the Ctrl+C keys.
trans-unit.target: On the Manage Keys Access page, select the text of the primary access key, and then choose the Ctrl+C keys.

trans-unit.source: In Azure Tools, paste the key into the Account key box.
trans-unit.target: In Azure Tools, paste the key into the Account key box.

trans-unit.source: You must select one of the following options to determine how the service will access the storage account:
trans-unit.target: You must select one of the following options to determine how the service will access the storage account:

trans-unit.source: Use HTTP. This is the standard option. For example, http://.blob.core.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: Use HTTP. This is the standard option. For example, http://.blob.core.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: Use HTTPS for a secure connection. For example, https://.blob.core.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: Use HTTPS for a secure connection. For example, https://.blob.core.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: Specify custom endpoints for each of the three services.
trans-unit.target: Specify custom endpoints for each of the three services.

trans-unit.source: You can then type these endpoints into the field for the specific service.
trans-unit.target: You can then type these endpoints into the field for the specific service.

trans-unit.source: If you create custom endpoints, you can create a more complex connection string.
trans-unit.target: If you create custom endpoints, you can create a more complex connection string.

trans-unit.source: When you use this string format, you can specify storage service endpoints that include a custom domain name that you have registered for your storage account with the Blob service.
trans-unit.target: When you use this string format, you can specify storage service endpoints that include a custom domain name that you have registered for your storage account with the Blob service.

trans-unit.source: Also you can grant access only to blob resources in a single container through a shared access signature.
trans-unit.target: Also you can grant access only to blob resources in a single container through a shared access signature.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to create custom endpoints, see <linkText>Configure Azure Storage Connection Strings</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to create custom endpoints, see <linkText>Configure Azure Storage Connection Strings</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To save these connection string changes, choose the OK button and then choose the Save button on the toolbar.
trans-unit.target: To save these connection string changes, choose the OK button and then choose the Save button on the toolbar.

trans-unit.source: After you save these changes, you can get the value of this connection string in your code by using <linkText>GetConfigurationSettingValue</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: After you save these changes, you can get the value of this connection string in your code by using <linkText>GetConfigurationSettingValue</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When you publish your application to Azure, choose the service configuration that contains the Azure storage account for the connection string.
trans-unit.target: When you publish your application to Azure, choose the service configuration that contains the Azure storage account for the connection string.

trans-unit.source: After your application is published, verify that the application works as expected against the Azure storage services
trans-unit.target: After your application is published, verify that the application works as expected against the Azure storage services

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publishing to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publishing to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>
